G.L. c. 208, \u00a7\u00a7 28, 31.proposition: A modification of custody or parenting time orders in Massachusetts is warranted when a material and substantial change in circumstances occurs, such that the modification is in the child’s best interests.

Ardizoni v. Raymond, 40 Mass. App. Ct. 7.raw_text: Ardizoni v. Raymond, 40 Mass. App. Ct. 734, 736 (1996)
Ardizoni v. Raymond, 40 Mass. App. Ct. 7.proposition: A modification of custody or parenting time orders in Massachusetts is warranted when a material and substantial change in circumstances occurs, such that the modification is in the child’s best interests.
Ardizoni v. Raymond, 40 Mass. App. Ct. 7.support_reasoning: The opinion directly quotes and applies G.L. c. 208, § 28, stating that a Probate Court may modify a prior custody judgment upon finding a material and substantial change in circumstances and that the modification is necessary in the children’s best interests. The court then analyzes whether such a material and substantial change occurred (the mother’s rehabilitation) and reiterates that the best interests standard governs custody modifications, thus squarely supporting the proposition about when modification is warranted in Massachusetts.
Ardizoni v. Raymond, 40 Mass. App. Ct. 7.relevant_excerpt: “General Laws c. 208, § 28, as amended through St. 1993, c. 460, enables a Probate Court judge, upon finding that ‘a material and substantial change in the circumstances of the parties has occurred’ to modify an earlier divorce judgment concerning the custody arrangements of minor children, where the modification ‘is necessary in the best interests of the children.’… When determining child custody awards in general, or modifications of custody awards based on changed circumstances, the guiding principle always has been the best interests of the children.”

G.L. c. 208, \u00a7 31.proposition: The best interests of the child are the paramount consideration in custody arrangements, as outlined in G.L. c. 208, § 31 and reinforced in Yannas v. Frondistou-Yannas, 395 Mass. 704, 710 (1985).

Yannas v. Frondistou-Yannas, 395 Mass. 7.proposition: The best interests of the child are the paramount consideration in custody arrangements, as outlined in G.L. c. 208, § 31 and reinforced in Yannas v. Frondistou-Yannas, 395 Mass. 704, 710 (1985).
Yannas v. Frondistou-Yannas, 395 Mass. 7.support_reasoning: The opinion explicitly interprets both the removal statute, G.L. c. 208, § 30, and the custody statute, G.L. c. 208, § 31, in terms of the ‘best interests of the child’ being the governing standard. In the section discussing removal, the court states that the statutory phrase ‘upon cause shown’ in § 30 ‘mean only that removal must be in the best interests of the child’ and then reiterates that ‘the best interests of the children always remain the paramount concern,’ directly supporting the proposition that best interests are paramount in custody/placement decisions under these statutes.
Yannas v. Frondistou-Yannas, 395 Mass. 7.relevant_excerpt: “The Massachusetts removal statute, G. L. c. 208, § 30 (1984 ed.), provides that… ‘upon cause shown’ mean only that removal must be in the best interests of the child (Rubin v. Rubin, 370 Mass. 857 [1976]; Hale v. Hale, supra at 815), and thus the central question in this case is how these ‘best interests’ are to be determined. … Although the best interests of the children always remain the paramount concern, ‘[b]ecause the best interests of a child are so interwoven with the well-being of the custodial parent, the determination of the child’s best interest requires that the interests of the custodial parent be taken into account.’”

Rosenberg v. Merida, 428 Mass. 182, 191.proposition: The material and substantial changes in circumstances in this case (the child’s advancement to school age, the father’s improved housing conditions, and the child’s expressed need for a revised schedule) meet the threshold for modification.
Rosenberg v. Merida, 428 Mass. 182, 191.support_reasoning: The case does apply the ‘material and substantial change in circumstances’ standard for modification of custody under G.L. c. 208, § 28, but it does not discuss or identify the types of changes listed in the proposition (school age, improved housing, child’s expressed need). Instead, it notes only that the judge found the parties were unable to communicate and then vacates the custody modification for lack of sufficient best‑interests findings. Thus, it neither holds that the specified circumstances meet the threshold for modification nor provides authority for that particular proposition.
Rosenberg v. Merida, 428 Mass. 182, 191.relevant_excerpt: “General Laws c. 208, § 28, provides that a Probate and Family Court judge may modify an earlier divorce judgment concerning the custody of a minor child on finding ‘that a material and substantial change in the circumstances of the parties has occurred and the judgment of modification is necessary in the best interests of the child[].’ … The only finding contained in the modification judgment is that ‘the parties are unable to communicate with one another.’ Although we express no opinion in this regard, that finding, if supported by the record, might be minimally sufficient to warrant a conclusion that a material and substantial change in the circumstances of the parties had occurred.”}

Custody of Kali, 439 Mass. 834, 841 (200.proposition: Furthermore, it has been established that continuity, stability, and the child’s emotional and developmental needs must guide schedule revisions.
Custody of Kali, 439 Mass. 834, 841 (200.support_reasoning: The opinion expressly emphasizes that in custody determinations judges should avoid unnecessary disruption of a child’s existing arrangements and that stability and continuity in caregiving are central to the child’s best interests. The court discusses preserving the status quo, the risks of rearranging living arrangements, and the importance of stability as a major factor in custody and scheduling decisions. This directly supports the proposition that continuity, stability, and the child’s emotional/developmental needs must guide schedule revisions.
Custody of Kali, 439 Mass. 834, 841 (200.relevant_excerpt: “It cautions against rearranging a child’s living arrangements in an attempt to achieve some optimum… when it is generally wiser and safer not to meddle in arrangements that are already serving the child’s needs. If the parenting arrangement in which a child has lived is satisfactory and is reasonably capable of preservation, it is ordinarily in the child’s best interests to maintain that arrangement… Stability is itself of enormous benefit to a child, and any unnecessary tampering with the status quo simply increases the risk of harm to the child.”

Pizzino v. Miller, 67 Mass. App. Ct. 865.raw_text: Pizzino v. Miller, 67 Mass. App. Ct. 865, 868 (2006)
Pizzino v. Miller, 67 Mass. App. Ct. 865.proposition: Massachusetts courts recognize that school-aged children require developmentally appropriate custody and visitation schedules conducive to their education, sleep routines, and emotional needs.
Pizzino v. Miller, 67 Mass. App. Ct. 865.support_reasoning: The opinion is a removal case focused on the Yannas 'real advantage' framework and the best interests analysis in the context of a custodial parent's relocation. While it mentions schooling quality, transition difficulties, and separation from family, it does not articulate any general principle that school-aged children require developmentally appropriate custody or visitation schedules tailored to education, sleep, or emotional routines. The case evaluates competing relocation factors rather than setting out or endorsing the specific developmental-schedule-focused rule stated in the proposition.
Pizzino v. Miller, 67 Mass. App. Ct. 865.relevant_excerpt: “In determining a child’s best interests, consideration must be given ‘to whether the quality of the child’s life may be improved by the change (including any improvement flowing from an improvement in the quality of the custodial parent’s life), the possible adverse effect of the elimination or curtailment of the child’s association with the noncustodial parent, and the extent to which moving or not moving will affect the emotional, physical, or developmental needs of the child.’ Yannas, 395 Mass. at 711.”

Mason v. Coleman, 447 Mass. 177, 184 (20.proposition: Both parties' willingness to agree to modifications is consistent with principles favoring cooperative parenting arrangements.
Mason v. Coleman, 447 Mass. 177, 184 (20.support_reasoning: The opinion does discuss that joint custody is appropriate when parents are able and willing to cooperate, but it does not address parties’ subsequent willingness to agree to modifications, nor does it frame such willingness as being ‘consistent with principles favoring cooperative parenting arrangements.’ The focus is on the need for cooperation to make joint custody viable, not on mutual modification behavior as an embodiment of cooperative principles. Thus the specific proposition is not supported by this case’s holding or reasoning.
Mason v. Coleman, 447 Mass. 177, 184 (20.relevant_excerpt: “Although the General Laws state that there is no presumption ‘either in favor or against shared . . . custody at the time of trial on the merits,’ G. L. c. 208, § 31, such an arrangement is generally appropriate only if the parties demonstrate an ability and desire to cooperate amicably and communicate with one another to raise the children. … ‘Joint custody is synonymous with joint decision making and a common desire to promote the children’s best interests.’”
